column1: #Text=Wikinews interviews Aurélien Miralles about Sirenoscincus mobydick species discovery
#Text=Aurélien Miralles with a Many-scaled Cylindrical Skink in Morocco in July 2012 .
#Text=, another species in the same genus .
#Text=The Sirenoscincus mobydick , dead specimen on a leaf .
#Text=A group of researchers published a paper about their discovery of a new species of Madagascar mermaid skink lizards last December .
#Text=The species is the fourth forelimbs-only terrestrial tetrapods species known to science , and the first one which also has no fingers on the forelimbs .
#Text=The species was collected at Marosely , Boriziny ( French : Port-Bergé ) , Sofia Region , Madagascar .
#Text=The Sirenoscincus mobydick name is after the existing parent genus , and a sperm whale from the 1851 novel Moby-Dick by Herman Melville .
#Text=This week , Wikinews interviewed one of the researchers , French zoologist Aurélien Miralles , about the research .
#Text=What caused your initial interest in Madagascar lizards ?
#Text=: Well , I would say that since I am a child I am fascinated by the biodiversity of tropical countries , and more especially by reptiles .
#Text=I did a PhD on the evolution and systematics of skink lizards from South America .
#Text=Then , I get a Humboldt grant to do a postdoc in Germany , at the Miguel Vences Lab , in order to study Malagasy skinks .
#Text=Madagascar being a fabulous hotspot for reptiles ( and not only for reptiles actually ) , it was a very nice opportunity .
#Text=Professor Vences proposed me to associate our complementary fields of expertise : he is expert in herpetology for Madagascar , and I am expert in skinks lizards ( family Scincidae ) .
#Text=It was a very fruitful experience , and many other results have still to [ be ] published .
#Text=: By a very funny coincidence actually .
#Text=In 2010 , I went to Madagascar for a long trip through the south of the island , in the semi-arid bush for collecting lizards and snakes samples .
#Text=Then , during the last days , just before coming back to Germany , I have visited by coincidence the zoological collection of the University of Antananarivo .
#Text=In that place , I found an old jar of ethanol with two weird little specimens previously collected by a student who did n't realize it was something new .
#Text=Being expert on skinks , I immediately recognised it was something very probably new , very different from all the other known species .
#Text=I am not the author of the genus name Sirenoscincus .
#Text=It has been described by Sakata and Hikida ( two Japanese herpetologists ) .
#Text=" Scincus " means skinks , a group of little lizards on which I am particularly focusing my studies .
#Text=So , Sirenoscinus means " mermaid skink " , in reference to [ the ] fact it has forelimbs but no hindlimbs .
